# Sign up for our newsletter! Stay informed on the latest DevOps news

Strengthening Software Trust in Modern DevOps Workflows

At swampUP 2025 in Napa Valley, Alan Shimel sat down with Tariq Shaukat, CEO of Sonar, and Gal Marder, EVP of Strategy at JFrog, for a discussion on how partnerships across the DevOps and AI ecosystems are reshaping the way software is built, secured and delivered.

Shaukat emphasized that Sonar’s relationship with JFrog is rooted in shared values around trust, transparency, and code quality. As AI continues to accelerate software creation, both companies see a growing need for solutions that help developers not only move faster but also maintain the highest levels of security and reliability. “It’s never been about how fast developers type,” Shaukat noted. “It’s about ensuring that what’s being built is safe, verifiable, and ready for production.”

The discussion also touched on the rising influence of AI in DevOps workflows and the responsibility that comes with it. Shaukat and Marder agreed that as teams adopt AI tools to generate, test, and deploy code, governance must evolve to keep pace. That’s where the partnership between Sonar and JFrog becomes especially relevant—bridging code integrity with artifact management, vulnerability detection, and software supply chain security.

Marder added that this collaboration exemplifies JFrog’s broader strategy to build a unified, secure DevOps ecosystem powered by trusted partnerships. Together, Sonar and JFrog are working to redefine how software quality and trust are measured in an era where AI agents, automation, and human developers all share the same pipeline.

Executive Security as a Strategic Priority

Step 1 of 8

12%

Which best describes your level of influence on cybersecurity, risk and/or data protection in your organization?(Required) I make decisions about or have influence over cybersecurity strategy

I make decisions about or have influence over risk strategy

I am responsible for protecting data at my organization

I am responsible for building and/or implementing solutions that protect the PII of employees and customers

I am responsible for building and/or implementing solutions to underpin our cybersecurity strategy

I am responsible for building and/or implementing solutions to manage and mitigate risk

Other/NA

Have you or members of your family or other executives and members of their families been targets of social engineering attacks? (Select All That Apply)(Required) I have personally been targeted

A member of my family has been targeted

Executives at my organization have been targets of AI social engineering attacks

Were any of the attacks successful?(Required) Yes

No

Don’t know

N/A

Which best describes your organization’s efforts to protect executives and their families against AI social engineering attacks?(Required) Has developed a strategy to protect executives and has begun to execute it

Has not addressed the impact of these attacks

Has made protecting executive PII a strategic priority and has a fully executed plan in place

Has discussed the potential impact of such attacks but has not executed a strategy

Has taken rudimentary steps to protect executives and their families

What challenges have prevented you from more fully securing the PII of executives and their families?(Required) Integration into existing security strategies

Potential disruption to business operations

Poor visibility into what should be protected

Tech spend is too high

Lack of executive/board support

Ease of use

Which of the following do you think are true about the level of threat posed by AI social engineering attacks?(Required) Obtaining executives’ available personal data online and that of their families can create extremely important leverage for threat actors seeking access to corporate assets

Executives have often handled the most sensitive data—often on the fly—and have access to a company’s most valuable assets from their homes and personal devices

AI social engineering attacks raise my organization’s risk exposure

AI social engineering attacks against executives and their families are on the rise, and we struggle to stay ahead of them

Protecting executives—and their families—should be a critical risk management priority

My organization doesn’t have a firm understanding of the risk from AI social engineering attacks

What steps has your organization taken to protect executives and their families from AI social engineering attacks? (Select All That Apply)(Required) Protect the integrity of confidential information and communications

Reduce attack surface

Invest in training

Block lateral movement

How valuable do you think it would it be to have an easy to integrate and use tool that protects the PII of executives and their families from AI social engineering attacks?(Required) Extremely valuable

Very valuable

Somewhat valuable

Slightly valuable

Not valuable
